newsitem.title: USA: Netscape to keep up the pace - magazine.
newsitem.headline: Netscape to keep up the pace - magazine.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp aims to continue setting a tough pace in Internet software development with a corporate focus on speed and a line-up of new products, according to Business Week magazine.
"We'll sacrifice almost anything for speed," Netscape chief financial officer Peter Currie was quoted as saying in the magazine's February 10 issue.
Business Week said Microsoft has adapted to the faster pace, posing challenges for Netscape.

"It's already clear that Netscape will never again have the huge lead it enjoyed its first two years," the magazine said. "But analysts say the company is making the right moves and if it can deliver on its promises it will continue to top the A-list of Internet software companies for the next five years, maybe longer."
Netscape had new products including Web infrastructure programs, the magazine said.
"Netscape's boldest plan revolves around a program code-named Constellation, which is aimed at one-upping the next release of Windows," the magazine said.
Like Microsoft's Windows, the Constellation browser would be used to manage functions performed on a computer, it said.
Netscape made progress very quickly, forcing competitors to keep up, it said.
For 1997, analysts expect sales to jump 45 percent, to more than $500 million, the magazine said.
